revision.text:
{{Sky|3|32|38.13|-|27|45|53.9|30000000000}} {{Infobox Galaxy | name = UDFy-38135539 | image = UDFy-38135539-HST-eso1041b-supercrop.jpg | image_size = 250px | caption= [[Hubble Space Telescope]] image of UDFy-38135539. | credit = | constellation name = [[Fornax]] | epoch = | type = Dwarf | ra = {{RA|03|32|38.13}} | dec = {{DEC|-27|45|53.9}} | z ≈ 8.6 | dist_ly = 13.1 [[Giga-|billion]] [[light-year]]s
([[Distance measures (cosmology)|light travel distance]])
~30 billion light-years
(present [[Comoving distance#Uses of the proper distance|proper distance]]) | stars = 1 billion (1×109) | appmag_v = V fainter than 30.2
H160 = 28.1
(detected by [[Hubble Space Telescope|HST]] in [[J band (infrared)|J]] and [[H band (infrared)|H bands]]) | size = 10,000 ly (diameter) | size_v = 0.0025 x 0.0025 | names = HUDF.YD3, TST2010 3, MDC2010 1721 }} [[File:UDFy-38135539-HST-eso1041b.jpg|thumb|upright|250px|UDFy-38135539 is within the annotated red circle]] [[Image:UDFy-38135539.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Location of UDFy-38135539 (HUDF.YD3)]] '''UDFy-38135539''' (also known as "HUDF.YD3") is the [[Hubble Ultra Deep Field]] (UDF) identifier for a [[galaxy]] which was calculated {{As of|2010|October|lc=on}} to have a light travel time of 13.1 [[Giga-|billion]] years with a present [[Comoving distance#Uses of the proper distance|proper distance]] of around 30 billion [[light-year]]s. It was discovered by three teams in September 2009 in sensitive infrared [[Hubble Space Telescope]] images and identified by these as source UDF-38135539 ([[Rychard Bouwens|R Bouwens]] ''et al.'',{{cite journal|author=R.J. Bouwens|author2=G.D.Illingworth|author3=P.A. Oesch|author4=M. Stiavelli|author5=P. van Dokkum|author6=M. Trenti|author7=D. Magee|author8= I. Labbe|author9=M. Franx|author10=M. Carollo| authorlink10 = C. Marcella Carollo| author11=V. Gonzalez|last-author-amp=yes|arxiv=0909.1803 |title=Discovery of z~8 Galaxies in the HUDF from ultra-deep WFC3/IR Observations |journal=Astrophysical Journal|volume=709 |issue=2 |pages=L133 |bibcode = 2010ApJ...709L.133B |doi = 10.1088/2041-8205/709/2/L133 |date=2010 }}) source HUDF.YD3 (A Bunker ''et al.''{{cite journal|author=Andrew Bunker|author2=Stephen Wilkins|author3=Richard Ellis|author4=Daniel Stark|author5=Silvio Lorenzoni|author6=Kuenley Chiu|author7=Mark Lacy|author8=Matt Jarvis|author9=Samantha Hickey|last-author-amp=yes |title=The Contribution of High Redshift Galaxies to Cosmic Reionization: New Results from Deep WFC3 Imaging of the Hubble Ultra Deep Field |journal=Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society|volume=409 |issue=2 |pages=855–866 |date=2009|arxiv=0909.2255|bibcode = 2010MNRAS.409..855B |doi = 10.1111/j.1365-2966.2010.17350.x }}) and source 1721 (R McLure ''et al.''{{cite journal|author=R.J. McLure|author2=J.S. Dunlop|author3=M. Cirasuolo|author4=A.M. Koekemoer|author5=E. Sabbi|author6=D.P. Stark|author7=T.A. Targett|author8=R.S. Ellis|last-author-amp=yes|arxiv=0909.2437 |title=Galaxies at z = 6 – 9 from the WFC3/IR imaging of the HUDF |journal=Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society|volume=403 |issue=2 |pages=960–983 |bibcode = 2010MNRAS.403..960M |doi = 10.1111/j.1365-2966.2009.16176.x |date=2010 |url=http://authors.library.caltech.edu/17971/1/McLure2010p7457Mon_Not_R_Astron_Soc.pdf}}), and additionally reported in the ''Astrophysical Journal'', and the ''Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society''. All teams independently identified the source likely an extremely distant galaxy because there was no measurable light at [[visible spectrum|visible wavelengths]] (caused by absorption of [[hydrogen gas]] along the line of sight). Following the discovery of this candidate distant galaxy, another team targeted this object with ground-based [[spectroscopy]] to confirm the distance, reporting a [[redshift]] z=8.6.{{cite journal |last1=Lehnert |first1=M. D. |last2=Nesvadba |first2=N. P. H. |last3=Cuby |first3=J.-G. |last4=Swinbank |first4=A. M. |last5=Morris |first5=S. |last6=Clément |first6=B. |last7=Evans |first7=C. J. |last8=Bremer |first8=M. N. |last9=Basa |first9=S. |title=Spectroscopic confirmation of a galaxy at redshift z = 8.6 |journal=Nature |volume=467 |issue=7318 |pages=940–942 |date=2010 |pmid=20962840 |doi=10.1038/nature09462 |arxiv=1010.4312 |bibcode=2010Natur.467..940L }} However, attempts to replicate this observation strongly suggest the original claim was in error, meaning that at the present time the galaxy only has a photometric redshift estimate.VLT/XSHOOTER & Subaru/MOIRCS Spectroscopy of HUDF-YD3: No Evidence for Lyman-alpha Emission at z=8.55 == Detection == Its first known imaging was in [[Hubble Space Telescope|Hubble telescope]]'s [[Hubble Ultra Deep Field]], the most detailed deep space picture at that time. The galaxy was observed in August and September 2009.{{cite web |url=https://www.newscientist.com/article/dn19603-dim-galaxy-is-most-distant-object-yet-found.html |title=Dim galaxy is most distant object yet found |publisher=New Scientist |accessdate=2010-10-21}}{{Cite journal|last=Matson |first=John |url=http://www.scientificamerican.com/article.cfm?id=farthest-galaxy |title=Early Bloomer: Faraway Galaxy Pushes Cosmic View Closer to the Dawn of the Universe |doi=10.1111/j.1365-2966.2009.16176.x |publisher=Scientific American|date=2010|arxiv = 0909.2437 |bibcode = 2010MNRAS.403..960M |volume=403 |issue=2 |journal=Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society |pages=960–983}} The image data was released to the scientific community, which led to the galaxy's detection by the teams of Bouwens, Bunker and McLure, and subsequent spectroscopic campaign by the team of Lehnert and colleagues.{{cite news|author=David Derbyshire |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sciencetech/article-1322166/UDFy-38135539-galaxy-13-billion-light-years-away-astronomers.html |title=Astronomers find most remote galaxy ever seen... 13 BILLION light years away |publisher=DailyMail.co.uk |date= 20 October 2010|accessdate=2010-10-21 |location=London}} Just on Hubble data, the galaxy could be an object intrinsically red and relatively close to [[Earth]], therefore, confirmation using suitably sensitive [[spectroscopy|spectroscopic]] equipment was needed. This was attempted using the [[European Southern Observatory]]'s SINFONI-equipped [[Very Large Telescope]] unit Yepun, located atop [[Cerro Paranal]] in [[Chile]]'s [[Atacama Desert]].{{cite web|author=Alan Boyle|url=http://cosmiclog.msnbc.msn.com/_news/2010/10/20/5322427-scientists-pinpoint-the-farthest-galaxy |title=Scientists pinpoint the farthest galaxy |publisher=MSNBC |date=2010-10-15 |accessdate=2010-10-21}}{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-11580789 |title=Galaxy is most distant object yet |publisher=BBC News |date= 20 October 2010|accessdate=2010-10-21}} Lehnert's team observed the galaxy for 16 hours, and then analysed their results over 2 months, and published their findings in ''[[Nature (journal)|Nature]]'', in October 2010. Since then, more sensitive measurements have failed to replicate the result, suggesting the spectroscopic claim was in error.{{cite journal | bibcode = 2013MNRAS.430.3314B | title=VLT/XSHOOTER and Subaru/MOIRCS spectroscopy of HUDF.YD3: no evidence for Lyman alpha emission at z = 8.55 | journal=Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society | volume=430 | issue=4 | page=3314 | year=2013 | author=Bunker, Andrew J. | author2=Caruana, Joseph | author3=Wilkins, Stephen M. | author4=Stanway, Elizabeth R. | author5=Lorenzoni, Silvio | author6=Lacy, Mark | author7=Jarvis, Matt J. | author8=Hickey, Samantha | doi=10.1093/mnras/stt132|arxiv = 1301.4477 }} == Characteristics == The galaxy is located in the constellation [[Fornax]], and is estimated to have contained roughly a billion [[star]]s,{{cite journal|last=Trenti|first=Michele|title=Astronomy: Galaxy sets distance mark|journal=Nature|volume=467|issue=7318|pages=924–925|date=2010|pmid=20962835|doi=10.1038/467924a|bibcode = 2010Natur.467..924T }} although it was only at most one tenth of the diameter of our own galaxy, the [[Milky Way]], and had less than 1% of the mass of the Milky Way's stars. According to Lehnert (of the [[Observatoire de Paris]]), it was forming the same number of stars per year as our galaxy, but they were much smaller and less massive, making it "intensely star forming".{{cite news |title=Earliest galaxy helped clear Big Bang's fog |publisher=USAToday |date=2010-10-20 |url=http://content.usatoday.com/communities/sciencefair/post/2010/10/earliest-galaxy-hubble/1}} The light travel distance of the light that we observe from UDFy-38135539 (HUF.YD3) is more than 4 billion [[parsec]]s (13.1 billion [[light year]]s), and it has a [[luminosity distance]] of 86.9 billion parsecs (about 283 billion light years).{{cite journal|last1=Lehnert|url=http://www.eso.org/public/archives/releases/sciencepapers/eso1041/eso1041.pdf|first1=M. D.|last2=Nesvadba|first2=N. P. H.|last3=Cuby|first3=J.-G.|last4=Swinbank|first4=A. M.|last5=Morris|first5=S.|last6=Clément|first6=B.|last7=Evans|first7=C. J.|last8=Bremer|first8=M. N.|last9=Basa|first9=S. |title=Spectroscopic confirmation of a galaxy at redshift z58.6 |doi=10.1038/nature09462 |accessdate=2010-10-27|journal=Nature |pmid=20962840 |volume=467 |issue=7318 |date=October 2010 |pages=940–2 |bibcode=2010Natur.467..940L|arxiv = 1010.4312 }} There are a number of different [[Distance measures (cosmology)|distance measures in cosmology]], and both "light travel distance" and "luminosity distance" are different from the [[comoving distance]] or "proper distance" generally used in defining the size of the [[observable universe]]{{cite journal | last = Davis | first = Tamara M. |author2=Charles H. Lineweaver | title = Expanding Confusion: common misconceptions of cosmological horizons and the superluminal expansion of the Universe | journal = Publications of the Astronomical Society of Australia | volume = 21 | issue = 1 | pages = 97–109 | date = 2004 | doi = 10.1071/AS03040 |arxiv=astro-ph/0310808|bibcode = 2004PASA...21...97D }}{{cite journal | last = Gott III | first = J. Richard |author2=Mario Jurić |author3=David Schlegel |author4=Fiona Hoyle |author5=Michael Vogeley |author6=Max Tegmark |author7=Neta Bahcall |author8=Jon Brinkmann | title = A Map of the Universe | journal = The Astrophysical Journal | volume = 624 | issue = 2 | pages = 463–484 | date = 2005 | doi = 10.1086/428890 | bibcode=2005ApJ...624..463G| arxiv=astro-ph/0310571 | url=http://www.astro.princeton.edu/universe/ms.pdf}} (comoving distance and proper distance are defined to be equal at the present cosmological time, so they can be used interchangeably when talking about the distance to an object at present, but proper distance increases with time due to the expansion of the universe, and is the distance used in [[Hubble's law]]; ''see'' [[Comoving distance#Uses of the proper distance|Uses of the proper distance]] for more on the physical meaning of this notion of 'distance'). The luminosity distance ''DL'' is related to a factor called the "comoving transverse distance" ''DM'' by the equation {{nowrap|''DL'' {{=}} (1 + ''z'') ''DM''}}, where ''z'' is the redshift, and the comoving transverse distance is itself equal to the radial comoving distance (i.e., comoving distance between an object and ourselves) in a spatially flat universe.Gabrielli, Andrea. ''Statistical Physics for Cosmic Structures'', [https://books.google.com/books?id=nYHRdjxKOEMC&lpg=PP1&pg=PA377 p. 377].{{cite web |url=http://www.mpifr-bonn.mpg.de/staff/hvoss/DiplWeb/DiplWebap1.html |title=A Cosmology and Cosmography |publisher=Mpifr-bonn.mpg.de |date=2005-09-21 |accessdate=2010-10-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110102134709/http://www.mpifr-bonn.mpg.de/staff/hvoss/DiplWeb/DiplWebap1.html |archivedate=2 January 2011 |df=dmy-all }} So with {{nowrap|''DL'' {{=}} 86.9 billion parsecs}} and {{nowrap|''z'' {{=}} 8.55}}, the comoving distance would be about 9.1 billion parsecs (about 30 billion light years).{{cite web |title=Cosmology Calculator I |publisher=Astronomy @ UCLA |author=Edward L. (Ned) Wright |url=http://www.astro.ucla.edu/~wright/CosmoCalc.html |accessdate=2010-10-22}} The infrared light that we now observe from the galaxy was emitted as ultraviolet radiation toward the end of an era when the universe was filled with atomic hydrogen, which absorbed at ultraviolet wavelengths. Because the galaxy's own light alone would not have been intense enough to ionize a large region and render it transparent, scientists suspect that a population of smaller, undetected galaxies, contributed to the reionization making UDFy-38135539 visible. == Significance == [[File:Hubble Ultra Deep Field diagram.jpg|thumb|300px|upright|Hubble looking into the past.]] The period of universal star birth was the [[reionization]] epoch. The universe's first stars were massive, ionizing hydrogen in the surrounding environment (''Trenti'').{{cite web|url=http://news.discovery.com/space/oldest-galaxy-universe-hubble.html |title=Oldest Object in Universe Found |publisher=Discovery News |accessdate=2010-10-21}}J Amos - 20 October 2010 - [https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-11580789 BBC News] Retrieved 2012-6-18MIT Haystack observatory - [http://www.haystack.mit.edu/ast/science/epoch/index.html ''index''] Retrieved 2012-06-18 UDFy-38135539 (HUDF.YD3) is thought to be one of the first galaxies observed in the reionization epoch. [[Caltech]] astronomer Brant Robertson, commenting on the study, stated that the "galaxy happens to reside at a very special time in cosmic history when the properties of gas in the universe were changing rapidly, and therefore this galaxy and others like it may teach us a lot about the early history of the universe". Michele Trenti, an astronomer who was not involved in the study but provided commentary published with the report, says that the discovery of the distant galaxy represents a {{quote|... fundamental leap forward in observational cosmology ...}} == Subsequent discoveries == Scientists hope to find older galaxies; however, closer to the Big Bang, fewer exist and they are dimmer on average. They will therefore be increasingly difficult to find, since they would be very faint with fewer observable stars. Trenti says that new "most distant" record holders will soon be announced, but only incremental distance gains will be realized until NASA's [[James Webb Space Telescope]] becomes operational in 2021. The James Webb telescope should be able to detect galaxies more than 13.4 billion light years away, less than 300 million years after the Big Bang. Bremer states that it, and eventually the [[European Extremely Large Telescope]], which will have a mirror five times the diameter of Yepun's, and is tentatively scheduled for first light in 2024, will enable more detailed study of galaxies at such great distances.{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/science/space/8075703/Most-distant-galaxy-identified.html |title=Most distant galaxy identified |publisher=Telegraph.co.uk |date= 20 October 2010|accessdate=2010-10-21 |location=London}} Lehnert states that this discovery is not "the limit, perhaps not even that close to it". At that time, Trenti said redshift 8.6 would likely to be as high as we can reach with the current generation of Earth-bound telescopes, but that with Hubble, "it might be possible to find some galaxies up to redshift 10". Candidates with higher redshifts than UDFy-38135539's have been reported subsequently, but not yet confirmed with light spectrum instruments., for example [[UDFj-39546284]] and [[MACS0647-JD]]. == See also == Other known most distant objects * [[GRB 090423]] is a gamma ray burst, which previously held the record for most distant object, and remains the most distant object with a spectroscopic redshift. * [[IOK-1]] is the previous record holder for the commonly accepted most distant galaxy. * The methods used to determine the distances to very distant cosmic objects are described in the "[[Cosmic distance ladder]]" == References == {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}} {{Commons category}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2010}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Udfy-38135539}} [[Category:Fornax (constellation)]] [[Category:Hubble Space Telescope]] [[Category:Dwarf galaxies]] [[Category:Astronomical objects discovered in 2009|20090910]] [[Category:Hubble Ultra-Deep Field]]

revision.comment: removed [[Category:Chinese astronauts]]; added [[Category:People's Liberation Army Astronaut Corps]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text:
{{Infobox astronaut |name = Wang Yaping |other_names = |image = Wang Yaping.jpg |caption = | type = [[China National Space Administration|CNSA]] Astronaut |status = |birth_date = April 1978 or January 1980 |birth_place = [[Yantai]], [[Shandong]], China |death_date = |death_place = |occupation = |current_occupation = |previous_occupation = |alma_mater = |rank = Colonel, [[People's Liberation Army Strategic Support Force|PLASSF]] |selection = [[List of astronauts by selection#2010|Chinese Group 2]]<ref>{{cite news |url= http://news.xinhuanet.com/english2010/china/2011-10/31/c_131222216.htm |title= China mulls over sending female "taikonauts" into space |date= 2011-10-31 |publisher= Xinhua |author= Xinhua }}</ref> |eva1 = |eva2 = |mission = [[Shenzhou 10]] |insignia = [[File:Shenzhou-10.png|40px]] |Date of ret = |awards = }} {{Chinese name|[[Wang (surname)|Wang]]}} {{Infobox Chinese |s=王亚平 |t=王亞平 |p=Wáng Yàpíng |mi={{IPAc-cmn|wang|2|-|ya|4|p|ing|2}} }} Colonel '''Wang Yaping''' (born January 27, 1980{{dubious|date=June 2013}}<ref>[http://baike.baidu.com/link?url=635p0GA1CdLeEmLjPjioeg7bATmnosBzN-_EWstCIcuc7GhENuWSa4a6pxZ6yG4pYonB-7fhKoK1RfvffQfN9hqsmYzV9BB_75NmJQGhdG3] {{dead link|date=February 2018}}</ref>) is a Chinese military pilot and [[astronaut]].<ref>[http://www.nasaspaceflight.com/2010/11/indentity-chinese-female-taikonaut-candidate-revealed/ Identity of one of the Chinese female taikonaut candidates revealed] NASAspaceflight.com</ref> Wang was the second female astronaut to be named by the [[CNSA]], and the second Chinese woman in space.
==Career== Wang was a captain in the [[People's Liberation Army Air Force]].<ref name="spacefacts">{{cite web|url=http://www.spacefacts.de/bios/international/english/wang_yaping.htm|title=Taikonaut (yuhangyuan) Biography: Wang Yaping|first=Joachim|last=Becker|website=Spacefacts.de|accessdate=11 April 2018}}</ref>
She was a candidate for the space mission [[Shenzhou 9]] in 2012.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.planetary.org/blogs/guest-blogs/jason-davis/china-readies-three.html|title=China readies three taikonauts for station visit|publisher=Planetary Society}}</ref> However, [[Liu Yang (astronaut)|Liu Yang]] was selected over her for the historic mission of the first Chinese female space traveller.<ref name=Space.com-2012-06-15/> Wang was a member of the backup crew for SZ-9.<ref name=SpaceDaily2013April03>{{cite news |url= http://www.spacedaily.com/reports/Shenzhous_Shadow_Crew_999.html |title= Shenzhou's Shadow Crew |author= Morris Jones |date= 3 April 2013 |publisher= Space Daily }}</ref>
Wang became the second Chinese female astronaut as a member of the [[Shenzhou 10]] spaceship crew, which orbited the earth in June 2013,<ref>{{cite news |title=Chinese astronauts complete space mission, return to Earth |author=William Harwood |newspaper=[[CBS News]] |date=June 25, 2013 |url=http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-205_162-57591038/ |accessdate=October 15, 2013}}</ref> and of the [[Tiangong-1]] orbiting space station with which it docked.<ref name="XinhuaJune10">{{cite web | url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/china/2013-06/10/c_132446006.htm | title=China to launch Shenzhou-10 manned spacecraft on June 11 | publisher=Xinhua | date=June 10, 2012 | accessdate=June 10, 2012}}</ref> She was the first member of the crew announced, in April, while the remainder of the crew were announced in June.<ref name=SpaceDaily2013April03/> Wang Yaping was one of two women in space on the 50th anniversary of [[Vostok 6]], the first spaceflight by a woman, [[Valentina Tereshkova]]. The other woman in space on 16 June 2013 was [[Karen Nyberg]], an American astronaut aboard the International Space Station.<ref>{{cite web |publisher= [[Universe Today]] |date= 16 June 2013 |title= Cosmonaut Valentina Tereshkova; 1st Woman in Space 50 Years Ago! Ready for Mars |author= Ken Kremer |url= http://www.universetoday.com/102956/cosmonaut-valentina-tereshkova-1st-woman-in-space-50-years-ago-ready-for-mars/ }}</ref> While aboard Tiangong-1, Wang conducted scientific experiments and taught a physics lesson to Chinese students by live television broadcast.<ref>{{cite news |first=Stephen |last=Clark |publisher=Spaceflight Now |title=Successful start for China's fifth human spaceflight |url=http://www.spaceflightnow.com/china/shenzhou10/130611launch/ |date=11 June 2013 |accessdate=11 June 2013}}</ref>
==Controversy== According to the official Shenzhou 10 report, Wang Yaping's birth date is stated as January 1980, which is incongruent with that of the Shenzhou 9 report. In the previous report, her birth date was April 1978.<ref name=CNTV>{{cite web | url=http://english.cntv.cn/special/shenzhou9/female/index.shtml | title=Female Astronaut - Shenzhou 9 Docking Mission with Tiangong-1 | publisher=[[China Network Television]] | accessdate=June 11, 2013}}</ref>
==Personal life== Wang is married, which one former official claimed is required for all women who are part of the Chinese space program due to concerns that spaceflight could potentially harm women's fertility.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Brenhouse|first1=Hillary|title=China's Female Astronauts: Must Be a Married Mom|url=http://content.time.com/time/world/article/0,8599,1974793,00.html|website=TIME|date=25 March 2010}}</ref><ref name=Space.com-2012-06-15>Space.com, [http://www.space.com/16158-china-female-astronaut-crew-shenzhou-9.html "China Unveils Astronaut Crew, 1st Female Spaceflyer, for Saturday Launch"], 15 June 2012, Clara Moskowitz</ref> However, this requirement has been officially denied by the director of the China Astronaut Centre, stating that this is a preference but not a strict limitation.<ref name="Want China Times">{{cite web | url=http://www.wantchinatimes.com/news-subclass-cnt.aspx?id=20120616000087&cid=1304 | title=For Liu Yang, sexism is still the final frontier | accessdate=June 17, 2012 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120620094637/http://www.wantchinatimes.com/news-subclass-cnt.aspx?id=20120616000087&cid=1304 | archivedate=June 20, 2012 | df= }}</ref><ref name="Wu Bin interview ">{{cite web | url=http://english.cntv.cn/program/newsupdate/20120616/107007.shtml | title=Exclusive interview: Astronauts selection process | publisher=[[CNTV]] | work=CCTV News | date=June 16, 2012 | accessdate=June 17, 2012}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Chinese women in space]] *[[List of female spacefarers|List of female astronauts]]
==References== {{reflist|2}}
==External links== *[http://www.spacefacts.de/bios/international/english/wang_yaping.htm Spacefacts biography of Wang Yaping]
